body: @happynear Let us simply provide the official link first. We can also suggest higher version of compiler, which might work or someone

@tqchen , to avoid lisence issues. I removed the zip archive links from build.md. Maybe a personal guidance in an issue is a better solution.

I will provide links to the vs2013 compiler patch and third-party libraries in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/250 , individually.
@antinucleon thanks ! I'll try this master branch.

## Problems you may come across when configuring mxnet in Visual Studio
- MXNet uses lots of C++11 features, which are not totally supported by Visual Studio 2013. Visual Studio 2015 provides better support for C++11/14, but it cannot work with any version of CUDA. 
  Fortunately, Microsoft has provided a patch, allowing VS2013 to support more C++11/14 features. The official page is [here](http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=41151). 
  Someone has reported that the patch cannot be installed successfully on their computer. I have archived and uploaded the files installed on my computer. You can download it from [OneDrive](http://1drv.ms/1RApcXr) or [BaiduYun](http://pan.baidu.com/s/1dVnJo).
- There are three third-party libraries should be installed, [OpenCV](http://sourceforge.net/projects/opencvlibrary/files/opencv-win/3.0.0/opencv-3.0.0.exe/download), [CuDNN](https://developer.nvidia.com/cudnn) and [OpenBlas](http://sourceforge.net/projects/openblas/files/v0.2.14/). You can download and install them from their official sites, or directly download all of them from [OneDrive](http://1drv.ms/1hzq9Cq) or [BaiduYun](http://pan.baidu.com/s/1kTrQmn9).
  It is suggested to create a `3rdparty` or `thirdparty` folder in the root of mxnet, and put the thirdparty libraries in each subfoldes, such as `./3rdparty/OpenBLAS`. 
- If your GPU's compute capability is less or equal to 2.1, you should remove `USE_CUDNN` when configuring CMake. You can look up for your GPU's compute capability in https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CUDA .
- Be careful that CMake will not give any warning or error if you haven't set the path of CUDNN. **Remember to set them.**
- When you are using Debug mode, please modify the variable `vs_configuration` defined in `./python/mxnet/libinfo.py` from `Release` to `Debug`.
- [PTVS](https://github.com/Microsoft/PTVS/releases) is a very powerful tool for editting and debugging python codes in Visual Studio. I strongly recommend you to install it.
kvstore_device 改为init的时候记录下所有values的shape，第一次update的时候初始化所有mergebuf，ps：代码里是不是还有其他地方会影响每个设备分配内存的大小的？发现每次起来极其，还是显存分布还是有些浮动

@happynear I apologize if my comments offend you. I did not mean anything against you. I just want to point out potential issues. This kind of licensing related issues could, for example, result in a [dmca takedown](https://github.com/github/dmca) of the whole repo in a worst case. But I do think what you do is very useful in practice for all windows users.
@tqchen Sure, I will do it tomorrow!

@pluskid , your warning is very instructive. I have removed the links that may cause lisence problems, and provided some "personal" suggestions in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/250 . 

I indeedly always ignore the lisence and pirate problems. I just want to bring convience to the users, because many of them would give up when they were facing even a small error.

For Windows, I do think provide prebuilt official setup.exe is feasible.

Other than that it looks good to me

Please use the [script](https://gist.github.com/thirdwing/e6b6939d365d882865b2) to list functions in specific environments.

`where` is a list and you can use `find.funs` or `lsall`.

``` r
> where <- c(paste("package:", "mxnet", sep = ""))
> lapply(where, find.funs)
[[1]]
 [1] "arguments"                      "as.array"                      
 [3] "init.ndarray.methods"           "init.symbol.methods"           
 [5] "is.MXNDArray"                   "is.MXSymbol"

 [9] "mx.gpu"                         "mx.nd.array"                   
[11] "mx.nd.clip"                     "mx.nd.dot"                     
[13] "mx.nd.internal.copyto"          "mx.nd.internal.div"

```

what's the example we are going to show lstm? i vote for char-lstm, char-level language model. https://github.com/karpathy/char-rnn

I have made a PTB example
https://github.com/antinucleon/mxnet/blob/master/example/LSTM/PennTree.ipynb
, however the behavior is abnormal when compared to torch.

At first 0.8 round, it is almost same to torch one, then torch make
perplexity from 700 to 300 in the last 0.2 of the first round, but ours
reduce from 700 to 670.

I spent a whole day on it and no luck to find out the reason.

I suggest to make the save/load interface consistent with each other: If I save a list, then I should get a list back from load; if I save an `mx.nd.array` object, I should get an `mx.nd.array` object from load.

Besides, I haven't found the way to save `mx.nd.array`s so that I can load back a list of more than one `mx.nd.array`.

The mx.nd.save is suppose to save a list of ndarrays. Because  there is no way to tell if the saved object is a list or array. We need to resort to two functions. For example Use `mx.nd.save.list` and `mx.nd.load.list` for current save and load
@mli Is there any example? I saw @antinucleon's LSTM example is build from scratch using low level symbol API so he knows exactly which symbol is data and which is label.

data seq is same to `symbol.list_arguments()` and outputs seq is same to `symbol.list_outputs`. So simply we can make a dict `dict(zip(sym.list_arguments(), exe.arg_arrays))` to map from name to NDArrary

I remember Openblas provided libgcc file, so there is no need to install
cgwin or mingw. I tested Cxxnet before,

Would you please provide an example similar to @Russell91's [apollocaffe based LSTMSummation](https://github.com/Russell91/LSTMSummation) which is more like a hello world of LSTM. It's much easier to debug and will get merged into the master branch sooner. Thanks a lot!
@futurely Thanks for your suggestion. I think I have located the bug and will fix in today or tmr

Thanks for pointing it out. This seems to mean chainer caches the kernels during compilation. Which is the individual operators. This is different from what was discussed in the note.

Having a computation graph is not restricted to programming styles(i.e. symbolic programs). In order to get gradient, imperative style program also need to track the computation graph. The difference is the restrictions on how each programming style can act on the graph

The nature of having to be `prepared for possible futures`` applys to imperative style programs, however. Which leads to things such as not being able to recycle memory even when user only want forward pass, and not being able to share memories, because user might reference them in future.

Great! May I further request an implementation of Bidirectional LSTM? Many papers have shown that it outperformed LSTM in language modelling, speech recognition, OCR and some other applications. There are implementations in [imperative programs](https://github.com/search?q=bidirectional+lstm&type=Code&utf8=%E2%9C%93) but almost none in symbolic programs.
@futurely Definitely. There will be bi-direction, IRNN, GRU and LSTM examples

I understand the difference between the two styles. This issue came to my mind when I was reading the [Model Checkpoint](http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/program_model.html#model-checkpoint) section. In the following snippet, only the computation graph is saved. After loading it back, it is compiled. Can the compiled `f` be saved too so that it can be loaded directly next time as well as the graph because the document said that the compilation created overhead?

```
A = Variable('A')
B = Variable('B')
C = B * A
D = C + Constant(1)
D.save('mygraph')
...
D2 = load('mygraph')
f = compile([D2])
# more operations
...
```

Oh, i see. We did not meant to mean compilation cost in this section, but simply mean being able to save/load a model.  We did not intend to discuss the computation caching here.

You are right that caching a compiled graph might speedup things.  The compilation overhead depends on the implementation, the optimization carried etc. It also means the engineering overhead to implement optimizations. 

You are more than welcomed to open a pull request to share your ideas as well :)
some changes related to #280

One minor thing about current implementation, is that it assumes the Push must be called after all Init calls. This is true for current use-case. It will be nice if the implementation can be improved, to the point such that it could also work for interleaving Init and Push(which is rare).

Thanks for contribution,  I have added your name to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.md  Please feel free to open PR if you like to add more details about you or contribute more to the project
Thanks , this is now fixed

According to the Amdahl’s law metioned in the document, only performance critical parts should be optimized. @joschu benchmarked the compilation time of CGT and Theano in "[Announcing CGT](http://joschu.github.io/)". A similar benchmark is needed before actually doing the optimization.
Thanks for pointing this out. I guess this can be done by adding a begin_round parameter to FeedForward. Are you interested in open a PR or this?
Yes, you are right. I a smartly chosen compilation strategy(that avoid complicated searches) might not be that slow as people thought.
@tqchen A merge conflict will happen because of #280, please cherry-pick my second commit and let me open new PRs later.

For the general ImageRecordIter we are doing shuffling locally per block. A block is a batch of image we load in(usually larger than batch size) as a unit in the data loader, and the shuffling going on for every block. Including the first epoch. So that logic https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/io/iter_image_recordio.cc#L350 is doing shuffling after one block is loaded in, and the iterator returns the images in the shuffled order.

It is harder to do a global shuffle, mainly due to cost random seek. So in general, what we can do is divide the data into blocks, load the blocks in random order, and shuffle the data within the block.

Current ImageRecordIter implemented within block shuffling, but did not yet implement random load of blocks

Currently the checkpoint only contains the symbol and the ndarrays. To save additional state, 
- we can either support saving of json string in the ndarray file(so saving anything that can be serialized into json). 
- Or use a special ndarray(epoch) to store the value.

The later probably needs less change.  I think we need to think a bit about this, since this trade simplicity of checkpt vs usability.
but why uses ndarray? to avoid frequently var create/delete for better performance?

One possible choice is to rely on language specific serialization technique to save extra solver state. It should be fairly easy to implement, but for that part of data it is no longer possible to, say save in Python and then load in Julia. Though I think most of the time, people won't do this "multi language training". And since we are implementing solvers in the specific script languages, each of them might have their own specific states that need to save and load, due to slight different implementation or language differences.
Thanks for clarification. Block-wise in memory shuffling totally makes sense.

I think at least in the long run we need to adopt more general ways here if we want to support restarting of any optimizers, including user-defined optimizers. Either to recover from a crash or to allow the user to explicitly run training again but for a more number of epochs.!

I see. Another reason for using NDArray by default is it helps you to resolve write dep tracking. Which could be nice way to resolve some of the concurrent writing issues of server side dep scheduling(which I assume ps-lite took some part). Otherwise the update need to append WaitToWrite/Read, which might not be perfect way to resolve the deps

The I/O and computation can be run in parallel with a graph like ImagePrefetching -> Transformation -> BufferedRecordSaving.

less than an hour, so parallel is not a good choice. And once you buffered
it, you can reuse every time

The major reason was the bottleneck of small image open and reading, which creates a lot of overhead.
This is capped by the filesystem. Because transforming is not bottleneck here. It is likely we don't gain much (still caped by the image loading speed) by doing a parallel pipeline. This was quite unfortunate, but is the major reason why we want to pack the images before use. 

To speed things up, running packings from multiple machines, or simply multiple disks(so the image reading can be done in parallel) in parallel should solve the problem.

It seems the problem is in the function `MXKVStoreSetUpdater`(c_api.cc, line 1003). When the lambda function is called, the `updater`'s access violates. I am not sure why windows behaves like this(maybe it is because the memory space of `updater` is across the edge between python and c++?). But you could simply add a line at line 1003 after `API_BEGIN();`,  `auto win_updater = std::move(updater);` and then use `win_updater` to replace `updater` in line 1008.
It works for me.

Fixed by #299

This was caused by lambda capture of function type instead of function pointer type. 

@mli We might need to be a bit careful about it in future, we could consider change the C API to accept the function pointer type instead.

All the parameters are in string format. We have some easy util to help you convert the strings to the target shape, and give you the desired parameters and do type checking.

Checkout https://github.com/dmlc/dmlc-core/blob/master/test/parameter_test.cc for example.
This issue is fixed by contribution #256  Thanks to @junranhe
